title: The tangled web of associational life: urban governance and the politics of popular livelihoods in Nigeria
abstract:
This paper examines how decentralisation and informalisation are\ud
reshaping urban governance in contemporary Africa. By exploring the interface\ud
between urban institutional failures and popular organisational solutions, the paper\ud
considers how informal governance processes feed into wider structural and political\ud
outcomes. Attention paid to issues of institutional process and power relations\ud
reveals how the limited access of the poor to resources and decision-making\ud
structures may distort rather than enhance their agency within decentralised urban\ud
governance systems. Drawing on case studies of informal enterprise associations in\ud
Christian and Muslim parts of Nigeria, this paper explores the differing ways in\ud
which networks of ethnicity, class and religion are used to forge links between\ud
dynamic informal organisational systems and formal institutions of government. The\ud
varied outcomes of these efforts raise uncomfortable questions about whether the\ud
proliferation of popular networks and associations amid weak formal institutions is\ud
